intro: Pteroselinum transsilvanicum, commonly known as Transylvanian parsley, is a herbaceous plant native to Central and Eastern Europe. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots, celery, and dill, and is characterized by its finely divided, aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with a slender stem and a basal rosette of leaves. Its flowers are small and white to pale yellow, arranged in umbels, and it produces small, smooth, black seeds. Pteroselinum transsilvanicum is often used in traditional herbal medicine and as a culinary herb.
